G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, the Lowell District Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action because the amount in controversy, including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, the Lowell District Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action because the amount in controversy, including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the cause of action arose in Lowell, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, where the Premises are located and where Plaintiff’s injuries occurred.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a store owner owes a duty to lawful business invitees to exercise reasonable care in the maintenance of its premises in a reasonably safe condition, to protect them against foreseeable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The excerpt provided is from a concurrence discussing the abandonment of rigid licensee/invitee distinctions, not directly the duty owed to business invitees. However, Mounsey v. Ellard as a whole is a leading Massachusetts case that rejects the old common-law classifications and holds that occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition against foreseeable harm. Thus, while the quoted passage does not itself state the rule, the case overall supports the proposition about a store owner’s duty to lawful business invitees.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: We hold that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The entrant’s status as an invitee or licensee is no longer to be determinative of the landowner’s duty. Rather, the basic duty is one of reasonable care in all the circumstances, including the obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the foreseeable risks of harm.

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 165\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a store owner owes a duty to lawful business invitees to exercise reasonable care in the maintenance of its premises in a reasonably safe condition, to protect them against foreseeable risks of harm.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 165\u2.support_reasoning: The case concerns a residential landlord’s duty to a tenant’s guest, not a store owner’s duty to business invitees. While the court generally adopts a negligence standard of reasonable care for landlords toward lawful visitors, it does not specifically discuss or establish the duty of a store owner to business invitees on commercial premises. Thus, it does not directly support the proposition about store owners under Massachusetts law.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 165\u2.relevant_excerpt: In Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973), we did away with the legal significance in tort of categories of licensee and invitee and held that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. We said: ‘The problem of allocating the costs and risks of human injury is far too complex to be decided solely by the status of the entrant….’

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–86 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Under Massachusetts premises-liability principles, a store’s duty of reasonable care includes liability where its own mode of operation and merchandising creates a foreseeable risk of harm to customers, even absent proof that it had actual notice of the specific falling item.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The court squarely adopts the mode-of-operation approach for Massachusetts premises liability in self-service stores and explains that, where the store’s chosen mode of operation makes such hazards reasonably foreseeable, the plaintiff’s proof of that mode substitutes for traditional proof of actual or constructive notice of the specific falling item. The opinion emphasizes that the owner has notice of risks inherent in its self-service merchandising and may be liable if it fails to take reasonable precautions, even without evidence of how long the grape was on the floor.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Of the two modem approaches, the mode of operation and burden-shifting approaches, the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it… Under the mode of operation approach, the plaintiff’s burden to prove notice is not eliminated. Instead, the plaintiff satisfies the notice requirement if he establishes that an injury was attributable to a reasonably foreseeable dangerous condition on the owner’s premises that is related to the owner’s self-service mode of operation… Adoption of this approach would not hold owners strictly liable… but would only make an owner liable if the owner could reasonably foresee that a dangerous condition exists and failed to take adequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.”}

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 52–53 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant also had a duty under Massachusetts common law to maintain its premises “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.”
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted text is from a dissent and deals exclusively with proximate cause, not with defining the scope of a premises-liability duty. The well-known Mullins language about a duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances appears in the majority opinion, not in this dissenting excerpt. Since the provided text neither states nor applies that common-law duty standard, this specific opinion text does not support the proposition cited for it.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a business proprietor must protect invitees against dangers of which it knows or reasonably should know.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The court expressly describes the traditional duty owed to invitees in Massachusetts as a duty of reasonable care that includes repairing or removing dangerous conditions or warning of dangers that are not known or obvious and of which the owner knew or reasonably should have known. It then extends that same reasonable-care standard to snow and ice hazards, reinforcing that a business proprietor must protect lawful visitors from dangers it knows or should know about. This directly matches the proposition stated.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” 457 Mass. at 371–72.

Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.raw_text: Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a business proprietor must protect invitees against dangers of which it knows or reasonably should know.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises in Massachusetts: to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe for patrons or at least warn them of dangers not likely to be known to them and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. That language directly reflects a duty to protect invitees against dangers the proprietor knows or reasonably should know about, matching the claimed proposition.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Nonetheless, even if Plaintiff were found to be partially at fault, which he expressly denies, Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, provides that Plaintiff may still recover damages so long as his negligence, if any, was not greater than the total negligence of Defendant, and such damages would be diminished only in proportion to any such negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 60F.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has sustained and will continue to sustain: a. Bodily injury, including a mild concussion, shoulder strain, pain, headache, dizziness, and other symptoms; b. Medical expenses, past and future, currently estimated at approximately $2,500 and subject to further proof at trial, which are recoverable under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 60F; c. Lost wages and loss of earning capacity, including approximately $1,200 in lost wages as a delivery driver; d. Physical pain and suffering; e. Mental anguish and emotional distress; f. Loss of enjoyment of life, including the inability to participate in his weekly soccer league for approximately one month; and g. Other damages to be determined at trial, all recoverable under Massachusetts negligence law.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has sustained and will continue to sustain: a. Bodily injury, including a mild concussion, shoulder strain, pain, headache, dizziness, and other symptoms; b. Medical expenses, past and future, currently estimated at approximately $2,500 and subject to further proof at trial, which are recoverable under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 60F; c. Lost wages and loss of earning capacity, including approximately $1,200 in lost wages as a delivery driver; d. Physical pain and suffering; e. Mental anguish and emotional distress; f. Loss of enjoyment of life, including the inability to participate in his weekly soccer league for approximately one month; and g. Other damages to be determined at trial, all recoverable under Massachusetts negligence law. See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 547–48 (1982) (discussing elements of negligence and compensable harms); Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass. 146, 149 (1990).
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: Payton v. Abbott Labs does not discuss the specific categories of damages listed in the proposition (concussion, shoulder strain, specific medical expense statutes, lost wages as a delivery driver, loss of enjoyment of life, etc.), nor does it set out the general elements of recoverable negligence damages in Massachusetts. The cited pages focus on negligent infliction of emotional distress, the requirement of physical harm for such claims, and prenatal injury issues, not a catalog of standard negligence damages. Thus it is not proper authority for the broad statement that all the enumerated damages are recoverable under Massachusetts negligence law or under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 60F.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "In summary, we hold that a plaintiff who alleges that she suffered injury in utero as a result of her mother's ingestion of a drug and that, but for the defendant's negligence, her mother would not have ingested that drug, has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted under Massachusetts law.... In summary, therefore, we answer that (1) absent physical harm, Massachusetts does not recognize a right of action for emotional distress..."

Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass.raw_text: Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass. 146, 149 (1990)
Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has sustained and will continue to sustain: a. Bodily injury, including a mild concussion, shoulder strain, pain, headache, dizziness, and other symptoms; b. Medical expenses, past and future, currently estimated at approximately $2,500 and subject to further proof at trial, which are recoverable under G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 60F; c. Lost wages and loss of earning capacity, including approximately $1,200 in lost wages as a delivery driver; d. Physical pain and suffering; e. Mental anguish and emotional distress; f. Loss of enjoyment of life, including the inability to participate in his weekly soccer league for approximately one month; and g. Other damages to be determined at trial, all recoverable under Massachusetts negligence law. See Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 547–48 (1982) (discussing elements of negligence and compensable harms); Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass. 146, 149 (1990).
Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass.support_reasoning: Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc. is a criminal procedure/Fourth Amendment and art. 14 search-and-seizure decision about an automobile stop, protective search, and the automobile exception. It does not discuss negligence, elements of a negligence claim, or categories of compensable personal injury damages under Massachusetts law, nor G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B or 60F. Citing Tassone for the listed negligence damages and compensable harms is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holdings or reasoning.
Tassone v. Tufts Assocs., Inc., 408 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The defendants argue that the warrantless search of the passenger compartment and the trunk of the Mercury and the containers found inside the trunk was unsupported by probable cause and therefore violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and art. 14 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights. The motion judge concluded that… Butler was also justified in conducting a protective search of the suspects and the area from which they might obtain a weapon… Once the officers discovered the cocaine and the handgun pursuant to the protective search, they had probable cause to search the entire automobile…”

Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 488, 495–96 (1983)
Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all of the above damages in accordance with Massachusetts law governing negligence and personal injury actions. See Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 488, 495–96 (1983); Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 86, 93 (1967).
Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the general measure of damages in Massachusetts negligence/personal injury cases—i.e., that a plaintiff may recover fair and reasonable compensation for all such damages. Glicklich addresses causation, apportionment of damages between successive negligent physicians, and the child’s right to recover for loss of parental society, but it does not articulate or endorse a general rule about the measure of damages in negligence actions. Any reference to damages here is case-specific (life expectancy, loss of parental society), not a statement of the broad compensatory-damages principle the proposition asserts.
Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Damages may be apportioned among two or more causes if there is a reasonable basis for doing so. Restatement (Second) of Torts § 433A (1965). There was evidence from which the jury could have found that due to Dr. Golub’s negligence the plaintiff’s life expectancy was shortened … The jury could have held Dr. Golub responsible for these conditions, then chosen to shift responsibility for any further damages incurred by the plaintiff to Dr. Spievack.”

Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 8.raw_text: Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 86, 93 (1967)
Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 8.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all of the above damages in accordance with Massachusetts law governing negligence and personal injury actions. See Glicklich v. Spievack, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 488, 495–96 (1983); Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 86, 93 (1967).
Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 8.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns amendment of pleadings after the statute of limitations, sufficiency of the negligence evidence against a gas company, evidentiary rulings, and jury instructions. It does not address the measure of damages or articulate any rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover “fair and reasonable compensation” for all personal injury damages. The citation to Wadsworth for a general Massachusetts damages standard in negligence/personal injury actions is therefore not supported by this text.
Wadsworth v. Boston Gas Co., 352 Mass. 8.relevant_excerpt: This evidence, if believed, would warrant a finding for the plaintiffs on either of two grounds: First, that Boston Gas undertook to locate and fix the cause of the odor of gas emanating from the stack heater and it failed to do so; or second, that under its own regulations, there was a duty to warn the Wadsworths that the stack heater was unsafe for operation.... The defendant’s motions for directed verdicts and for the entry of verdicts under leave reserved were not specifically based on the pleadings.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim arises under Massachusetts common law of negligence, as informed by, including but not limited to, the following authorities, which are cited in support of the duty, breach, causation, and damages alleged above:

G.L. c. 231.proposition: Pursuant to the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and G.L. c. 231, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
